Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Anterior deltoid Lateral third of clavicle Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Flexion, IR, Adduction
Lateral deltoid Acromion Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Abduction
Posterior deltoid Scapular spine Deltoid tuberosity of humerus Axillary n.
C5 - C6		 GHJ: Extension, ER, Abduction
``` ::: ::: # Overview The deltoid is divided into 3 parts and 7 functional units. | Parts | Components | |-|-| | [Anterior part](#anterior-head) | I & II | | [Lateral](#lateral-part) | III | | [Posterior](#posterior-part) | IV, V, VI, & VII | II, III, and IV lie lateral to the abduction axis and produce abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. I, V, VI, and VII act as adductors. I and V are conditional and act as adductors when the upper limb hangs down vertically @jonesProjectFoundations2025. VI and VII *always* act as adductors @jonesProjectFoundations2025. | Component | a | Action | |-|-|-| | I | | | | II | Lateral to abduction axis | Abduction | | III | Lateral to abduction axis | Abduction | | IV | Lateral to abduction axis | Abduction | | V | | | | VI | | Adduction | | VII | | Adduction | : @jonesProjectFoundations2025 {.striped} # Anterior head ### Origin {#origin} Lateral 1/3 of clavicle @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ![Left Clavicle (superior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image200 gray1918 Left clavicle. Superior surface.gif){#fig-gray1918-image200} ![Left clavicle (inferior view) @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Osteology/image201 gray1918 Left clavicle. Inferior surface.gif){#fig-gray1918-image201} ### Insertion Humerus (deltoid tuberosity) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Innervation {#innervation} [Axillary n. {{< var ref-axillary-nerve.roots >}}]({{< var ref-axillary-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Action {#action} Flexion, internal rotation, adduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Lateral part :::{layout-ncol="2"} ### Origin {#origin} Acromion @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Insertion Humerus (deltoid tuberosity) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Innervation {#innervation} [Axillary n. {{< var ref-axillary-nerve.roots >}}]({{< var ref-axillary-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Action {#action} Abduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ::: :::{.callout-note} *Between 60 and 90 degrees of abduction, the clavicular and spinal parts assist the acromial part with abduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ::: # Posterior part ### Origin {#origin} Scapular spine @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Insertion Humerus (deltoid tuberosity) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Innervation {#innervation} [Axillary n. {{< var ref-axillary-nerve.roots >}}]({{< var ref-axillary-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ### Action {#action} Extension, external rotation, adduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 :::{.callout-note} *Between 60 and 90 degrees of abduction, the clavicular and spinal parts assist the acromial part with abduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 ::: # Abduction Activation The deltoid is active at the start of abduction and achieve full abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The deltoid's peak efficiency occurs at 90° @jonesProjectFoundations2025. It can generate up to 8.2x the weight of the upper limb @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ### Pure abduction Pure abduction occurs in the frontal plane. - Component III of lateral deltoid recruits first - IV and V of posterior deltoid recruit immediately after @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - Component II (anterior delt) recruits after the first 20-30° @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ### Scapular plane abduction Scapular plane exists between the sagittal and frontal planes. 30° from the frontal plane @jonesProjectFoundations2025. 1. II (anterior deltoid) and III (lateral deltoid) are recruited first @jonesProjectFoundations2025. 1. IV and V (posterior deltoid) and I (Anterior deltoid) are recruited progressively later @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ### External rotation into abduction 1. II (anterior deltoid) contracts at the start ::: {.callout-note} IV and V (Posterior deltoid) do not contract at all during this movement @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: ### IR to abduction "recruitment order reverses" @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Clinical Relevance As the GHJ becomes more unstable, the deltoid muscle takes on more of a stabilizing role @kidoDynamicStabilizingFunction2003 # Strength Testing # Palpation # Dysfunction # Strain-Counterstrain ::: {.callout} Strain counterstrain for the "bursa" or "deltoid muscle" @myersClinicalCounterstrain2012. "BURSA (Deltoid Muscle) Location of Tender Point: Flex or abduct the arm to 90° to allow palpation beneath the acromion process by shortening and relaxing the deltoid muscle. Anatomical Correlation: Any part of the deltoid muscle. Direction to Press on Tender Point: Press from superior to inferior with the arm in the stated position above. Treatment Position(s): With patient supine or seated, the shoulder is flexed or abducted 90° to 120°. Rotation varies from slightly internal to slightly external depending on the part of the deltoid muscle that is involved. Frequency of Occurrence: Uncommon to rare. Many muscles refer pain to the area of the deltoid muscle and most of the time it is not the deltoid causing the pain. Wag Clinical Correlation(s): Pain in the anterior, lateral, or posterior shoulder over the deltoid depending on which part of the muscle is involved. Associated Pain Referral Pattern: Pain in the upper arm. Alternate Names/Nomenclatures: None. Explanatory Notes: None." @myersClinicalCounterstrain2012 :::
